description: Ultimately from Middle French harpie, from Latin harpyia, from Ancient Greek Ἅρπυια (Hárpuia, literally “snatcher”), from ἁρπάζω (harpázō, “I snatch, seize”). Compare rapacious. Middle English had arpie.

entries.meaning: (mythology) A mythological creature generally depicted as a bird-of-prey with the head of maiden, a face pale with hunger and long claws on her hands personifying the destructive power of storm winds.
One who is rapacious or ravenous; an extortioner.
examples: The harpies about me all pocket the pool.

entries.meaning: The European moor buzzard or marsh harrier (Circus aeruginosus).
A large and powerful double-crested, short-winged American eagle (Harpia harpyja).
